Should always have a Tested: with new-function code. Can just say "Detailed tests will be in last commit of this series" if you just want to test it all at once.

I was little struggeled with tests due to the difference between master and downstream, since the code difference is huge many times a one to one mapping of change is not available. which is complicating the testing and master can be used only for building not testing, anyway created a new test setup with 1050 now I am directly able to test master code with that
ok, add "Tested:" to commit message?
Done
I'd vote INFO here since we could see this happen in fail scenarios where multiple services are requesting dumps. Seeing error traces for this obfuscates the real error causing all the dump requests.
Done
Doesn't seem done?
missed
Why would we not just call the function above this with a single entry in the vector?
+1 "const std::vector<std::string>& fullPaths" used to support mutiple files package option.
The dump collector picks only one file at a time, even if we have multiple files only first one is picked.
The initial design to support mutiples file based on dump type if required. I would like to keep the existing flow here.

But there is no use for that since the dreport is not accepting it, and if there is any usecase in future, we should add a vector of paths as part of the variant in the create parameters. I dont think we need it until we have  that support.

Here you are trying to remove the existing support. Unless there is strong reason for removing this , not a good idea to remove the existing working code. 
Note: There is already review in progress to package mutiple core file as part of dump, in this case we can use the existing interface with out any change.

The current interface does support multiple paths, but the underlying implementation doesn't. When a commit to package multiple core dumps into a single dump was pushed, I asked this question to the community via Discord, the consensus was that there should be one core dump per dump. Thus, if there are multiple core dumps, the core monitor would need to initiate multiple calls to package each dump individually.

Given this, in our current use cases, only one file needs to be added to each dump. If a new type of dump requires packaging all files in a folder, the folder can be directly sent to the dreport, allowing the script to process the specific dump accordingly.

Should we encounter a rare use case in the future where files from multiple locations need to be collected for packaging, we'd need to discuss the best approach at that time. However, I think such a scenario is unlikely because a special dump type typically handles a specific use case and should package either a single file or multiple files from a specific folder.

In instances where multiple files must be packaged for a use case, a client application should collect the information from each file to be sent. In such cases, the client application can consolidate all the data in a temporary folder and send the folder name as part of the call.

Given these considerations, I don't see a compelling reason to maintain an array of files here

ok, seems reasonable, but can we delete the interface above that takes the vector of files as input? Seems confusing to have both. May be a good topic to throw up on our overflow call if we just need to talk this one out a bit.
The interface is internal and that is getting deleted in the future commit Addin to the overflow

"but can we delete the interface above that takes the vector of files as input? Seems confusing to have both".  +1
Since this is internal interface,not impacted outside pdc, cleaner approach is push a separate commit with this particular change with provide detailed descriptions.

I originally pushed a commit with removing the interface and made it granular based on the comments, now I didn't get how just this change will be a separate commit, because that will end up with a compiler error right?
Do you mean why this function is still kept? it is because we are moving step by step to the new interface, which is why still this is kept to avoid build errors and function breaks.

Oh, I see, it gets deleted in https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-debug-collector/+/63877/43/dump_manager_bmc.hpp. Makes sense now. So initially we said we'd support passing multiple files, so we created an interface for that. But in practice, we never did that and the back end doesn't support it. So we're moving to just accepting one file (which is all the back end supports). If we ever run into a use case where we need multiple files we'll revisit but...we've been going for a long time now without needing it.
by defining const type map , you can move this initialization to hpp.

Moving the functions using the table to dump_types.cpp

I'd prefer this just be a helper function in your new dump_type.cpp so we don't have to externalize this table (allowing for abstraction from it) in the surrounding code. In fact, maybe you just move this whole function in there.
yes that is better, will move this function to the dump_types.hpp/cpp
